questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triclabendazole

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections because:

 

  • It is the latest and most effective drug available
  • Has excellent activity against both immature and mature flukes
  • Single dose treatment is often effective
  • Well-tolerated with minimal side effects
  • WHO recommended first-line treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Albendazole:

 

  • More effective against nematodes
  • Limited efficacy against liver flukes
  • Not recommended as first-line therapy for fascioliasis

 

Option C. Mebendazole:

 

  • Primarily used for treating intestinal nematodes
  • Poor absorption and bioavailability
  • Not effective against liver flukes

 

Option D. Praziquantel:

 

  • While effective against most trematodes
  • Has poor efficacy against Fasciola species
  • Used mainly for schistosomiasis and other fluke infections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

questions.text: A patient was injured with a rusted metal object. What is the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin in such cases?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

 

Tetanus toxin, also known as tetanospasmin, is produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. When a person is injured by rusted metal, this bacterium can enter the body and produce the toxin. Tetanospasmin specifically targets the nervous system by binding to receptors on motor nerve terminals and getting internalized. It then travels retrogradely to the central nervous system where it inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons.

 

GABA and glycine normally function to inhibit motor neurons and prevent excessive muscle contraction. By blocking these neurotransmitters, tetanospasmin causes unopposed muscle contractions, leading to the characteristic muscle spasms and rigidity seen in tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibit the release of Acetylcholine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit acetylcholine (Ach) release. Instead, botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum inhibits the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis rather than muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Inhibit the release of epinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not affect the release of epinephrine. Epinephrine release is primarily regulated by the adrenal glands and not significantly impacted by tetanospasmin.

 

Option D. Inhibit the release of norepinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit the release of norepinephrine. Norepinephrine release is also regulated by different mechanisms and is not directly influenced by tetanospasmin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin) inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contractions and the characteristic spasms of tetanus.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. It occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream causing an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis.

 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections are:

 

  • Food poisoning - caused by enterotoxin
  • Toxic shock syndrome- caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome- caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by the release of TSST-1 and other superantigens leading to severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliative toxins leading to the destruction of the skin's epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not mediated by toxins, unlike staphylococcal food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which are all toxin-mediated infections.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment –

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

choices.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice
Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute angled branching aspergillus

 

The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45°) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

 

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains.

 

The following image shows LPCB mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtuse angled mucor: Mucor produces non-septate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

 

Option B. Acute angled penicillium: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

 

Option D. Obtuse angled Rhizopus: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain shows characteristic features of Aspergillus species. These features include acute-angled (45°) uniform branching septate hyphae.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs. of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The rapid onset of gastroenteritis symptoms within 4-6 hours after consuming the sandwiches suggests a preformed toxin in the food. Staphylococcus aureus is known for producing enterotoxins that cause food poisoning with a short incubation period of 2-6 hours. This bacterium can contaminate food through contact with a carrier who handles food without proper hygiene. In this case, the cook is likely the carrier, having contaminated the sandwiches, leading to the outbreak of gastroenteritis among the picnic attendees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, which has a longer incubation period (6-30 days), making it unlikely to cause symptoms so quickly.

 

Option B. Vibrio cholera: This bacterium causes cholera, characterized by severe diarrhea and dehydration, with an incubation period of a few hours to 5 days, but it typically results from contaminated water rather than food prepared by a cook.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which generally has a longer incubation period (2-4 weeks), and it is usually associated with contaminated water or food.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Level D will show parasitic ova in formal ether sedimentation test.

 

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris.

 

Option B. B: This level is where the plug of debris is found after centrifugation.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formal ether sedimentation technique separates parasitic elements based on their specific gravity. Parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is given below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E. Histolytica

 

  • The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir.
  • The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer.
  • The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces.
  • Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.
  • The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.
  • The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, has a simple life cycle that involves ingestion of eggs, hatching in the intestine, and laying eggs around the anus. It does not form trophozoites or cysts.

 

Option B. A. duodenal: Ancylostoma duodenale, a hookworm, has a life cycle involving skin penetration by larvae, migration through the bloodstream to the lungs, ascent to the throat, and finally ingestion to the intestine where they mature. It does not have cysts or trophozoites.

 

Option C. B. coli: Balantidium coli is a ciliate protozoan with a life cycle that involves a cyst stage and a trophozoite stage, similar to E. histolytica. However, it is characterized by the presence of cilia and typically associated with pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective

 

The life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica includes the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst stages, with transmission primarily by the fecal-oral route. The most frequent site of systemic disease caused by E. histolytica is the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JC Virus: Known for causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in patients with severe immunodeficiency, but it is less common than CMV in affecting renal transplant patients in the early months post-transplant.

 

Option C. BK Virus: This virus can affect renal transplant recipients by causing BK virus-associated nephropathy, which can lead to graft dysfunction and loss. However, its peak incidence typically occurs slightly later than CMV.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): While EBV can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not as commonly the predominant pathogen in the early post-transplant period compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and managing CMV infection in the early months following renal transplantation is crucial due to its potential to cause significant morbidity and impact on graft survival. Monitoring for CMV activity and initiating pre-emptive or therapeutic antiviral treatment as indicated is key to improving transplant outcomes.

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

choices.text: Thayer Martin agar
Wilson Blair agar

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. The best culture media for the following organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thayer Martin agar

 

The patient’s symptoms of urethral discharge, dysuria, and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse suggest an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a fastidious bacterium requiring enriched media for growth. Thayer Martin agar is a selective medium specifically designed to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It contains nutrients that support the growth of Neisseria species and antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to inhibit the growth of contaminating organisms, making it the best medium for culturing this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood agar: Although blood agar is a general-purpose nutrient medium that can support the growth of a wide range of bacteria, it is not selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and does not contain the necessary inhibitors to prevent the growth of other organisms.

 

Option B. MacConkey agar: This agar is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria and is typically used for isolating lactose-fermenting bacteria like Escherichia coli. It is not suitable for the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which does not thrive on this medium.

 

Option D. Wilson Blair agar: This medium is used for isolating Salmonella typhi and is not relevant to Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as it does not provide the specific growth conditions required for this organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thayer Martin agar is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a bacterium associated with sexually transmitted infections presenting as urethral discharge and dysuria.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

 

The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

 

Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. This technique allows for a presumptive diagnosis of syphilis even before antibodies have developed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Phase contrast microscopy:

 

  • Phase contrast microscopy enhances the contrast of transparent specimens without staining. It is often used for live cells and other transparent samples.
  • The background in phase contrast microscopy is not typically as dark as in darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscopy

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorophores to stain specific structures, which then emit light when exposed to specific wavelengths. The images typically show bright fluorescent colors against a dark background.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy

 

  • Electron microscopy uses a beam of electrons to create an image. The images produced are typically in black and white with extremely high resolution, showing detailed structures at the nanoscale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

 

  • The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.
  • Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid-fast staining technique.

 

 

Option C: The image given below is of a gram-stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii.

 

 

Option D: The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

choices.text: Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

 

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.

 

Causative organism - Cryptosporidium hominis (more common), C.parvum

 

Causes intractable diarrhoea in immunocompromised patients.

 

Infective form - oocyst.

 

The oocyst is spherical or oval and measures about 5 μm in diameter. Oocyst does not stain with iodine and is acid-fast. The wall of the oocysts is thick, but in 20% cases, wall may be thin. These thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection.

 

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of the oocysts in feces.

 

  • A direct wet mount reveals colorless, spherical oocyst of 4-5 μm, containing large and small granules.
  • The oocysts are difficult to visualize in unstained wet preparations. Modified ZN staining is the method of choice and by this method oocysts appear as red acid-fast spheres, against a blue background.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathogen does not show autoinfection: This is incorrect. Cryptosporidium can indeed cause autoinfection. Thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection, perpetuating the infection within the host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide: While Cryptosporidium parvum is a common cause, Cryptosporidium hominis is more frequently implicated in human infections worldwide.

 

Option D. It is an obligate intracellular organism: Cryptosporidium is not strictly obligate intracellular; it can survive outside the host as an oocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.

 

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

 

The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5-10 mg/kg once).

 

H. nana egg is colorless, almost transparent, oval, non-bile stained, 30–50 µm (micrometers) in diameter, has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have a 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells.

 

Shell consists of two distinct membranes; inner membrane has two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is used to treat infections caused by various nematodes and ectoparasites but is not effective against cestodes like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option C. Albendazole: Albendazole is an effective treatment for various helminth infections, including some cestodes, but praziquantel is specifically preferred for Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option D. Diethylcarbamazine: Diethylcarbamazine is used primarily for treating filarial infections, not cestode infections like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Educational Objective

 

Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful
  4. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

 

Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.

 

H. ducreyi is a small, fastidious gram-negative rod that requires an enriched growth medium cultivated in a high humidity, CO2-enriched environment. On Gram stain, long strands of organisms are seen in a pattern often referred to as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" in appearance.

 

Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre." Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in "kissing ulcers." The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months.

 

Other Option:


D. Groove sign: This is typically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and not chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

 

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves T cells, particularly cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) and helper T cells (TH1 cells). When these T cells recognize antigen presented by antigen-presenting cells (like macrophages and dendritic cells), they secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells. This leads to an inflammatory response that can cause tissue damage. The process typically takes 24-72 hours to develop, hence the term "delayed."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Macrophages play a crucial role in presenting antigens and secreting cytokines, but they are not the primary cells involved in mediating the type IV hypersensitivity response.

 

Option C. Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells are important antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells, but they are not the main effector cells in type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions, where they mediate tissue damage through the release of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in response to immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: A young boy developed keratitis after careless use of contact lenses due to unhygienic lens fluid. Microscopy showed an organism with spike-like pseudopodia. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba that is commonly found in water and soil. It can cause keratitis, particularly in individuals who use contact lenses with poor hygiene. Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain, redness, blurred vision, and the presence of corneal ulcers. Microscopic examination often reveals an organism with distinct spike-like pseudopodia, which is a key identifying feature of Acanthamoeba. This amoeba adheres to the corneal surface and invades the tissue, leading to infection and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Balantidium: Balantidium coli is a protozoan parasite known to cause intestinal infections (balantidiasis) primarily in humans and other primates. It does not cause keratitis or have spike-like pseudopodia.

 

Option C. Naegleria fowleri: Naegleria fowleri, also known as the "brain-eating amoeba," causes primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), a rare and often fatal brain infection. It does not typically present with keratitis or spike-like pseudopodia.

 

Option D. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause a variety of infections, including conjunctivitis and other ocular infections, but it does not present with spike-like pseudopodia under microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For contact lens-related keratitis involving an organism with spike-like pseudopodia, Acanthamoeba is the most likely cause. It is essential to maintain proper hygiene with contact lenses to prevent such infections.

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process used for plasma can safely inactivate all lipid-enveloped virus. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it's not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.

 

Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): HIV is an enveloped virus. The SD process effectively inactivates HIV by disrupting its lipid envelope, making it non-infectious.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBV is also an enveloped virus. The SD process disrupts the lipid envelope of HBV, rendering it non-infectious.

 

Option D. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV): HCV is another enveloped virus. The SD process targets and inactivates HCV by disrupting its lipid envelope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process inactivates lipid-enveloped viruses such as HIV, HBV, and HCV. However, it does not inactivate non-enveloped viruses like Hepatitis A Virus (HAV), making HAV infections a potential risk during SD plasma transfusion.

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a salt-loving organism commonly associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw or undercooked oysters. It can cause gastroenteritis characterized by symptoms like watery or bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The Kanagawa phenomenon, which is the hemolysis of human red blood cells on a special medium, is specifically linked with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, further confirming its presence in this case. This bacterium's name also hints at its association with blood ("hemolyticus"), which aligns with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism typically causes food poisoning with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but it is not associated with bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not specifically related to seafood.

 

Option B. Salmonella typhi: This organism causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea, but not typically bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not linked with seafood consumption or being salt-loving.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera is associated with severe watery diarrhea, it does not cause bloody diarrhea or present with the Kanagawa phenomenon. Vibrio cholera also differs from Vibrio parahaemolyticus in its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV 2

 

In this scenario, the 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. The Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells, which are indicative of a herpes virus infection. Given the mother’s history of genital lesions, it is highly suggestive that the baby contracted the infection during delivery.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Vesicles: The presence of vesicles (fluid-filled blisters) is characteristic of herpes infections.
  • Tzanck Smear: This test shows multinucleate giant cells, which are typical findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.
  • Mother's Genital Lesions: This detail strongly indicates genital herpes, which is most commonly caused by HSV-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella Zoster: Although varicella zoster virus (VZV) can cause vesicles and multinucleate giant cells, the history of maternal genital lesions and the clinical presentation points more specifically towards HSV.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: This bacterium is not associated with vesicular lesions or multinucleate giant cells on Tzanck smear. It typically causes urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and endocarditis, not the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis can cause congenital infections but does not present with vesicular skin lesions or multinucleate giant cells. The typical findings include intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis

 

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation.

 

Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells (medlar/copper penny bodies)

 

The following are the various dematiaceous species of fungi

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

 

Treatment: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions. The application of local heat is also beneficial.

 

MEDLAR/ SCLEROTIC BODIES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It does not typically present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: Pheohyphomycosis is a broad term for infections caused by dematiaceous fungi but lacks the characteristic sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with lymphocutaneous lesions but does not show the sclerotic bodies characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

choices.text: Mannitol salt agar
Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
Sorbitol MacConkey agar

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

O157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol salt agar: This medium is primarily used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species because it contains high concentrations of salt, inhibiting most other bacteria.

 

Option B. Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: Used for the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species, which are also important enteric pathogens.

 

Option D. CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium: Designed for urinary tract infections to inhibit the swarming of Proteus species and allow the differentiation of other urinary pathogens based on lactose fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.

choices.text: Hydrogen peroxide
Methyl paraben
Bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not a sanitizer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Process of bringing down levels of pathogenic organisms on inanimate surfaces to reduce the chances of cross-infection is called as sanitization.

 

Process of destroying all pathogenic organisms is called as disinfection.

 

Process of eliminating all microorganisms in both vegetative and spore state are eliminated from a surface or medium is called as sterilization.

 

Hydrogen peroxide works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack membrane lipids, DNA, and other essential cell components. Catalase, produced by aerobic organisms and facultative anaerobes that possess cytochrome systems, can protect cells from metabolically produced hydrogen peroxide by degrading hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. This defense is overwhelmed by the concentrations used for disinfection.

 

Disinfection or sterilization of cystoscopes, endoscopes, tubing’s, and metal instruments can be done with liquid form of hydrogen peroxide while gaseous form can be used for fogging. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Penicillin, an antibiotic. It is neither a disinfectant nor a sanitizer.

 

Option C. Methyl paraben is a type of paraben. Parabens are chemicals that are often used as preservatives to give products a longer shelf life.

 

Option D. Household bleaching powder (sodium hypochlorite) is used as a disinfectant in hospitals. Diluted solutions can be used for sanitizing surfaces.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydrogen peroxide is used as a disinfectant because it effectively destroys a wide range of pathogenic organisms. It is not typically used as a sanitizer, which is a process aimed at reducing, rather than completely eliminating, pathogenic organisms on surfaces.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas-based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."

 

The sterilization chamber is evacuated and hydrogen peroxide solution is injected from a cassette and is vaporized in the sterilization chamber to a concentration of 6 mg/l. The hydrogen peroxide vapor diffuses through the chamber (50 minutes), exposes all surfaces of the load to the sterilant, and initiates the inactivation of microorganisms. An electrical field created by a radio frequency is applied to the chamber to create a gas plasma. Microbicidal free radicals (e.g., hydroxyl and hydroperoxyl) are generated in the plasma. The excess gas is removed and in the final stage (i.e., vent) of the process the sterilization chamber is returned to atmospheric pressure by introduction of high-efficiency filtered air. The by-products of the cycle (e.g., water vapor, oxygen) are nontoxic and eliminate the need for aeration.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethylene oxide: Ethylene oxide is a gas used for sterilization, particularly for items that cannot withstand high temperatures. It is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are used for radiation sterilization, a different method that utilizes high-energy photons to sterilize equipment. They are not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option D. UV rays: UV rays are used for surface sterilization and disinfection. They are not part of the plasma sterilization process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma sterilization makes use of hydrogen peroxide vapor, which is activated into a plasma state by an electrical field, generating microbicidal free radicals that effectively inactivate microorganisms. This method is efficient and leaves nontoxic by-products, making it suitable for sterilizing sensitive medical and laboratory equipment.

questions.text: All are features of Zika Fever except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petechial rash

 

Petechial rash is not a feature of Zika Virus. Though petechia may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of Dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash is not typically associated with Zika virus infection. It is more commonly associated with Dengue fever, where petechiae (small red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin) are a common feature.

 

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

 

The complications of Zika virus are:

 

  • Gullian Barre Syndrome
  • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guillain-Barre syndrome: Zika virus has been linked to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can cause severe muscle weakness and even paralysis.

 

Option C. Fever with arthritis: Fever with arthritis or arthralgia is a common feature of Zika virus infection.

 

Option D. Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (red eyes) is a frequent symptom of Zika virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika fever typically presents with a maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, fever, and arthralgia, and it can be complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome. Petechial rash is not a common feature and is more indicative of Dengue fever.

questions.text: Match the following:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correct matching of the diseases with their diagnostic techniques is as follows:

 

  1. Leprosy - d. Split skin smear
  2. Tinea capitis - c. KOH wet mount
  3. Contact dermatitis - b. Patch test
  4. Lupus vulgaris - a. Biopsy

 

Other options:

 

The other options provided in the multiple choice (A, B, and C) are incorrect matchings of the diseases and diagnostic techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each skin condition has a specific diagnostic test:

 

  • Leprosy is diagnosed using a split skin smear, typically from the earlobe.
  • Tinea capitis, a fungal infection, is diagnosed using a KOH wet mount of skin, nail, or hair scrapings.
  • Contact dermatitis is evaluated using a patch test to identify allergens.
  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is diagnosed through a skin biopsy to look for granulomas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

choices.text: Heat till it become red hot

questions.text: Inoculation loops are commonly sterilized by which method? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat till it becomes red hot

 

Inoculation loops are typically made of nichrome wire with a circular structure at one end and a wooden handle. The most appropriate method for sterilizing these loops is heating them until they become red hot, which is a type of physical heat method. This method ensures complete sterilization of the metal portion of the loop that comes in contact with microorganisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclaving:

 

  • Incorrect because autoclaving is not suitable for inoculation loops as it would be impractical and unnecessary
  • Autoclaving is primarily used for bulk sterilization of media, equipment, and materials at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI

 

Option B. Microwave:

 

  • Incorrect because microwave sterilization is not appropriate for metal objects like inoculation loops
  • Microwaves can cause arcing with metal objects and potentially damage the equipment

 

Option C. Passing over flame 3 times:

 

  • Incorrect because this method is specifically used for degreasing glass slides
  • This technique would not provide sufficient heat to ensure complete sterilization of the inoculation loop

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inoculation loops must be sterilized by heating till red hot to ensure complete elimination of microorganisms, as this is the most effective and practical physical heat method for these instruments.

choices.text: Toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green
Carbol fuschin and methylene blue
Carbol fuschin and malachite green
Toluidine and methylene blue

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toluidine blue ‘O’ and malachite green

 

Albert stain is a type of differential stain used for staining high-molecular-weight polymers of polyphosphate known as metachromatic granules or volutin granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Metachromatic granules are also found in Yersinia pestis, and Mycobacterium species.

 

Albert stain is composed of two reagents:

 

  • Albert’s A solution consist of
    • Toluidine blue - 0.15 gm
    • Malachite green - 0.20 gm
    • Glacial acetic acid - 1 ml
    • Alcohol (95% ethanol) - 2ml

 

Dissolve the dyes in alcohol and add to the distilled water and acetic acid. Allow the stain to stand for one day and then filter. Add Distilled water to make the final volume 100ml.

 

  • Albert’s B solution consist of
    • Iodine - 2gm
    • Potassium iodide (KI) - 3 gm
    • Dissolve KI in water and then add iodine. Dissolve iodine in potassium iodide solution

 

Albert stain is basically made up of two stains that are toluidine blue’ O’ and malachite green both of which are basic dyes with high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. The pH of Albert stain is adjusted to 2.8 by using acetic acid which becomes basic for volutin granules as the pH of volutin granule is highly acidic. Therefore, on applying Albert’s stain to the smear, toluidine blue’ O’ stains volutin granules i.e the most acidic part of cell and malachite green stains the cytoplasm blue-green. On adding Albert’s iodine due to effect of iodine, the metachromatic property is not observed and granules appear blue in color.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is typically used in acid-fast staining (Ziehl-Neelsen stain) for mycobacteria.

 

Option C. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is not typically used for staining metachromatic granules.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is not specific for metachromatic granules and is not used in Albert staining.

 

Educational Objective
