Albert stain, which contains Toluidine blue 'O' and Malachite green, is specifically used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. These granules are an important diagnostic feature for diphtheria.

choices.text: To hold and support the specimen slide
To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen
To adjust the focus and clarity of the image

questions.text: What is the primary function of the condenser in a compound microscope? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

 

The condenser in a compound microscope is a crucial component located within or below the stage (sub-stage). Its primary function is to gather and concentrate light from the microscope's illuminator and direct it into a light cone that focuses on the specimen.

 

Condenser Function:

 

  • Light Regulation: The condenser focuses and concentrates the light onto the specimen to ensure optimal illumination, which is critical for viewing the specimen clearly.
  • Improving Image Quality: By regulating and directing the light precisely, the condenser enhances the contrast and clarity of the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To magnify the specimen image: Magnification is achieved by the objective lenses and eyepiece, not by the condenser.

 

Option B. To hold and support the specimen slide: The stage is the part of the microscope that holds and supports the specimen slide, not the condenser.

 

Option D. To adjust the focus and clarity of the image: Focus adjustment is achieved using the coarse and fine adjustment knobs, not the condenser.

 

Parts of Microscope

questions.text: Among the options provided, which protozoan parasite is found within Kupffer cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmania donovani

 

  • Kupffer cells are macrophages of Liver.
  • Amastigote form of Leishmania donovani is engulfed by macrophages monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells → LD-body
  • LD bodies seen in peripheral smear of a patient with Kala azar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes

 

Option C. Babesia’s life cycle doesn’t involve liver. Sporozoites directly enter RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax: In the pre-erythrocytic stage, plasmodium sporozoites invade hepatocytes, where they undergo development into merozoites. Subsequently, these merozoites infiltrate red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amastigote form of Leishmania donovani, also known as LD bodies, is found within macrophages, including Kupffer cells in the liver, during infection.

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

 

  • The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy blood group antigen, is protective against P. vivax because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.
  • Drug Efflux pumps are the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).
  • Algid malaria is a rare complication of severe malaria characterized by hemodynamic collapse manifesting as shock with pronounced metabolic changes and hypothermia.
  • Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale.
  • Malaria relapse:
    • True relapse is caused due to Hypnozoites.
    • These are resting forms.
  • In the case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which:
    • multiply inside hepatic cells to form - Schizonts
    • others persist and remain dormant as - hypnozoites
  • From time to time some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In the case of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence technically relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India: This statement is correct. Drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum are a significant concern in India.

 

Option C. Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: This statement is correct. Algid malaria is a rare but severe complication of malaria characterized by shock and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option D. Relapse is seen in P. ovale: This statement is correct. Relapse is seen in Plasmodium ovale as well as Plasmodium vivax due to the presence of hypnozoites.

 

Educational Objective

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax, not its presence.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgE

 

Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is specifically associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. In the context of chronic allergies, such as asthma, hay fever, and other allergic conditions, IgE levels are typically elevated. IgE binds to allergens and triggers histamine release from mast cells and basophils, leading to the symptoms of allergic reactions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily found in mucous membranes, secretions like tears, saliva, and colostrum, and plays a critical role in mucosal immunity.

 

Option B. IgM: IgM is the main antibody of primary immune responses and is effective at fixing complement. It is also found as a monomer on the surface of B cells.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is the most abundant antibody in blood and extracellular fluid, providing the majority of antibody-based immunity against invading pathogens. It is the main antibody involved in secondary immune responses and can cross the placenta.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

 

This clinical history is suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis which is caused by Actinomyces israeli.

 

Actinomyces are non-sporeforming, filamentous, and facultative anaerobes. They are normal constituents of the oral flora within gingival crevices and tonsillar crypts and are particularly prevalent in periodontal pockets, dental plaques, and on carious teeth.

 

Actinomyces bacteria cannot penetrate healthy tissue, and mucosal breakdown is a prerequisite for infection. Poor dental hygiene, caries, oral trauma, dental extraction, and an immunocompromised status are considered to be important antecedents.

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis or lumpy jaw is the most frequent clinical form of actinomycosis, and “lumpy jaw syndrome”, which is associated with odontogenic infection, is the most common clinical manifestation.

 

It presents as a painless or occasionally painful soft-tissue swelling involving the submandibular or perimandibular region; over time, multiple sinuses drain pus containing sulfur granules; tendency to remit and recur. There is reddish or bluish discoloration of the skin overlying the lesion, chewing difficulties (i.e., with involvement of mastication muscles) are also seen.

 

Other types -

 

  • Thoracic actinomycosis- 
    • History of aspiration (Risk factors include seizure disorder, alcoholism, and poor dental hygiene.)
    • Dry or productive cough, occasionally blood-streaked sputum, shortness of breath, chest pain pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- 
    • History of abdominal surgery, perforated viscus, mesenteric vascular insufficiency, or ingestion of foreign bodies (e.g., fish or chicken bones)
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- 
    • History of IUCD
    • Lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge

 

A Gram-stained smear of the specimen may demonstrate the presence of beaded, branched, gram-positive filamentous rods, with a sun ray appearance suggesting the diagnosis of actinomycosis.

 

 

Culture - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies.

 

Treatment - Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin’s such as amoxicillin are now popular. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: This is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions, typically affecting the lower extremities. It does not present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: This is a severe fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. It usually affects immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral or pulmonary infections, not typically associated with submandibular masses and sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, primarily affecting the lungs and sometimes disseminating in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti Hbc Ab

 

The Anti-HBc antibody (C) is the marker that will always be present in a patient's serum if they have been exposed to Hepatitis B virus (HBV). This marker is indicative of both past and ongoing infection and remains detectable for life. It indicates a previous or ongoing infection with HBV and is present in both acute and chronic stages of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is typically not detectable in the serum. It is found within the hepatocyte and not usually present in the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Anti HBs Ab: The antibody against the Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to HBV, either from past infection or vaccination. It is not present during chronic infection without recovery.

 

Option D. HBe Ag: Hepatitis B e antigen is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is not present in all stages of infection, especially in chronic carriers where the virus may not be actively replicating.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae

questions.text: Pneumonia caused by a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive. Identify the microorganism. (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemophilus influenzae

 

Findings are suggestive of Hemophilus influenza.

 

Hemophilus influenza –

 

  • Slender, short, gram negative rods or coccobacillus
  • Non-Motile, no flagella or pilli
  • Capsules are present and important in pathogenicity.
  • Encapsulated form are coccobacilli, CSF Sample
  • Non-Capsulated are pleomorphic, long, thread, filamentous
  • Fastidious Microorganism

 

Culture:

 

  • Blood Agar: translucent, low, convex or flat pin point colonies, Satellitism.
  • Chocolate Agar: Grayish, Transparent, smooth, low, convex or flat with a slightly splayed out, entire edge, mucoid, pale
  • In liquid medium like Levinthal’s Broth or Filde’s Broth: Uniform Turbidity.

 

Hemophilus influenzae biochemical reactions-

 

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae can cause many kinds of infections. Which can range from mild ear infections to severe diseases, like meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae bacteria most often cause pneumonia, bacteremia, and meningitis mostly in infants and children younger than five years of age.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. coli: Although it can cause pneumonia, E. coli is typically a gram-negative rod that grows on MacConkey agar and is not usually pleomorphic. It is catalase-positive but not typically grown on chocolate agar.

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: This genus includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a gram-negative rod that grows on various media, including nutrient agar and MacConkey agar. It is oxidase-positive but does not typically present as pleomorphic.

 

Option D. Actinomyces: This is a gram-positive bacterium and not relevant to this question as it does not fit the gram-negative description.

 

Educational Objective

 

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive. It is a common cause of respiratory infections, including pneumonia, particularly in young children.

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: Identify the organism given below. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microsporum


The image provided shows a hair shaft with white-colored structures inside, characteristic of endothrix infection, where the fungal elements are present within the hair shaft. Endothrix infections are typically caused by Trichophyton species such as Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum. However, since these specific Trichophyton species are not listed as options, the Ans.  is determined by excluding the other choices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: This option is incorrect because Trichosporon is associated with white piedra, not endothrix infections. Trichosporon causes superficial infections that present as white nodules on hair shafts, which is distinct from the endothrix appearance.

 

Option B. Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton does not infect hair. It is known for infecting skin and nails but never the hair, which rules it out as the causative organism in this scenario where the infection is clearly within the hair shaft.

 

Option D. Candida: Candida typically causes mucocutaneous infections and is not involved in hair shaft infections, making it an unlikely candidate for the description provided.

 

Educational Objective:


Endothrix infections involve fungal elements within the hair shaft, commonly caused by specific Trichophyton species. In the absence of these species as answer options, the organism that affects hair (Microsporum) should be considered.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a child presenting with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasma

 

The presentation of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is highly indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect the fetus during pregnancy if the mother acquires the infection. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis
  2. Hydrocephalus
  3. Diffuse parenchymal calcifications

 

These parenchymal calcifications are distributed throughout the brain tissue, which is a key distinguishing feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zika virus: Zika virus infections are primarily associated with microcephaly, calcifications in both the gray and white matter, and other severe brain malformations, not specifically with parenchymal calcifications along with hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to multiple defects, including hearing loss, heart defects, and cataracts. However, it is not typically associated with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Congenital CMV infection is commonly associated with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse parenchymal calcifications. This means calcifications are found around the ventricles of the brain rather than throughout the parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: An adult male patient presented with the following condition on his private parts. A gram-negative diplococci was found in the gram stain. The drug of choice for treatment is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tab Cefixime 400 mg

 

The patient presents with discharge from the penis, and the gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci. This is characteristic of an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common sexually transmitted infection that causes urethritis in males, characterized by purulent discharge and dysuria. The drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae is Cefixime 400 mg, which is effective against this bacterium due to its broad-spectrum activity against gram-negative organisms, including Neisseria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tab Azithromycin: Azithromycin is often used in combination therapy for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, but it is not the primary treatment for Neisseria gonorrhoeae alone.

 

Option C. Tab Doxycycline 200 mg: Doxycycline is used primarily for chlamydial infections and is not the drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Inj. Benzathine Penicillin: Penicillin is used for treating syphilis, another sexually transmitted infection, but it is not effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae due to the development of resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, characterized by gram-negative diplococci and purulent discharge, the recommended treatment is Cefixime 400 mg.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

 

The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

 

The causative agent is Chlamydia trachomatis, serovars L1, L2, L3. Chlamydia is a ubiquitous ovoid or obligate intracellular bacteria.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum primarily affects the lymphatic system. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars extend from the primary infection site to the regional lymph nodes and cause a lymphoproliferative reaction, facilitated by binding of Chlamydia trachomatis to the epithelial cells. Binding occurs via heparin sulfate receptors.

 

The basis for a definitive diagnosis of LGV is on serology tests (complement fixation or micro-immunofluorescence) or identification of Chlamydia trachomatis in genital, rectal and lymph node specimens (by culture, nucleic acid amplification test or direct immunofluorescence).

 

Educational Objective

 

The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii is typically made through serology for specific antibodies rather than Giemsa staining.

 

Giemsa stain is a differential stain which is made up of a combination of reagents (Azure, Methylene blue, and Eosin dye) used widely in cytogenetics and histopathology for the diagnosis of:

 

  • Malaria, spirochetes and other blood parasites
  • Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion bodies
  • Borrelia spp
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Histoplasma spp
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci cysts
  • Bartonella henselae
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Talaromyces marneffei (formerly called Penicillium marneffei)

 

In parasitology to detect intraerythrocytic (plasmodia, babesiae) and exoerythrocytic (trypanosomes, microfilaria) parasites. It is also used for the detection of intracellular amastigotes of Leishmania species or Trypanosoma cruzi. Giemsa stain is also used for the laboratory diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii: Giemsa stain is used for the laboratory diagnosis of toxoplasmosis, which involves the detection of intracellular organisms.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae: Giemsa stain can be used to identify Bartonella henselae, particularly in blood smears.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Giemsa stain is effective in diagnosing infections caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis by identifying the morulae within white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. Serology for specific antibodies is the method used for its diagnosis. Giemsa stain is a versatile stain used to diagnose a variety of blood parasites and intracellular pathogen.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

choices.text: Toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.

 

Definitive hosts - Members of Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts.

 

Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents). Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

 

Life cycle of toxoplasma gondii

 

  1. Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat’s feces. Although oocysts are usually only shed for 1–3 weeks, large numbers may be shed.
  2. Oocysts take 1–5 days to sporulate in the environment and become infective. Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water or plant material contaminated with oocysts.
  3. Oocysts transform into tachyzoites shortly after ingestion. These tachyzoites localize in neural and muscle tissue and develop into tissue cyst bradyzoites.
  4. Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts. Cats may also become infected directly by ingestion of sporulated oocysts.
  5. Animals bred for human consumption and wild game may also become infected with tissue cysts after ingestion of sporulated oocysts in the environment.

 

Humans can become infected by any of several routes:

 

  • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts
  • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat).
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation.
  • Transplacentally from mother to fetus.
  • In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes; these cysts may remain throughout the life of the host.

 

 

Diagnosis is usually achieved by serology, although tissue cysts may be observed in stained biopsy specimens.

 

Diagnosis of congenital infections can be achieved by detecting T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid using molecular methods such as PCR

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cystoisospora: Causes isosporiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Its lifecycle involves humans as the definitive host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Causes cryptosporidiosis, an intestinal illness. The lifecycle involves direct fecal-oral transmission.

 

Option C. Plasmodium knowlesi: Causes malaria, with a lifecycle involving mosquitoes as vectors and humans as host.

 

Educational Objective

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: False about the Ebola virus is: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmitted by mosquito

 

Ebola viruses belong to a family of viruses termed Filoviridae. Filovirus particles form long, sometimes branched, filaments of varying shapes, as well as shorter filaments. Viral particles contain one molecule of single-stranded negative-sense RNA, enveloped in a lipid (fatty) membrane.

 

Mode of transmission - direct contact with blood or other bodily fluids, such as semen, feces, or vomit, of infected persons (or animals), including close contact with deceased EVD victims, which are highly infectious.

 

Reservoir hosts – Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir

 

Accidental Hosts – Man

 

Incubation period - 2 to 21 days.

 

Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Nosocomial transmission seen.

 

Symptoms – severe headache muscle and joint pain, weakness and fatigue, sore throat, loss of appetite, gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting, Unexplained hemorrhaging, bleeding or bruising.

 

Treatment – symptomatic and supportive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a filovirus: This is true. Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and forms filamentous viral particles containing single-stranded negative-sense RNA.

 

Option C. Bats act as reservoir: This is true. Fruit bats are considered the most likely natural reservoir hosts for the Ebola virus.

 

Option D. Nosocomial transmission seen: This is true. Nosocomial transmission, which occurs in healthcare settings, is a recognized mode of transmission for Ebola virus, often due to inadequate infection control practices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is a filovirus transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals, not by mosquitoes. Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir, and nosocomial transmission is a known route of spread.

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that is often found intracellularly within neutrophils. It is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections, including infections of the Bartholin glands. The typical presentation includes swelling and pus discharge, which is consistent with the given clinical scenario.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is characterized by its kidney or bean shape and lack of a capsule, unlike Neisseria meningitidis, which is capsulated. It is known for causing sexually transmitted infections, including those affecting the genital tract, such as Bartholin gland abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Although Chlamydia can cause genital infections, it is not a Gram-negative diplococcus. Instead, it is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a unique developmental cycle.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid is a Gram-negative bacillus and not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, which is not a Gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next best step of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

 

Given patient with fever and filarial antigen test positive points to diagnosis of filariasis. And the next best step for this patient is the detection of microfilariae in the blood smear.

 

The gold standard method to diagnose active infection is by demonstrating microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopy.

 

It is critical and should be based on the periodicity of the microfilariae. For nocturnal periodicity, blood should be collected between 9 pm and 2 am.

 

DEC provocation test is done to collect the blood in the day time. Patient takes a tablet of DEC orally (2mg/kg) so that the nocturnal microfilariae are stimulated and come to peripheral blood within 30 minutes.

 

Although there is an advantage of blood sample collection even during day time, the guidelines from CDC, NVBDCP, and IAPSM suggest blood sample collection at night, followed by identification of microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopic examination as the standard method for diagnosis.

 

Other methods to detect adult worms include:

 

  • Lymph node biopsy to detect adult worms.
  • X-ray (if worms are calcified)
  • High-frequency ultrasound and doppler of the scrotum (Option D).
  • Serology - Antigen detection by using monoclonal antibodies against Og4C3 and AD12 antigens.
  • ELISA and ICT

 

Treatment - Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) → DOC. Given orally in a dose of 6 mg per kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days. It kills microfilariae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone Marrow Biopsy: Not relevant for filariasis, as it does not involve the bone marrow.

 

Option B. DEC Provocation Test: While useful for driving microfilariae into the peripheral blood for easier detection during daytime, it is less direct than a nighttime blood smear.

 

Option D. Ultrasound of the Scrotum: Useful in chronic cases to detect adult worms in lymphatic vessels, particularly in cases of lymphatic filariasis affecting the scrotum, but not as immediate or definitive for acute diagnosis as a blood smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct confirmation of active filarial infection, detection of microfilariae in a blood smear is essential. This method provides clear evidence of the parasites in the bloodstream, crucial for diagnosing and managing filariasis effectively.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Filariasis

 

Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

 

Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is targeted for global elimination through treatment of entire at-risk populations with repeated annual mass drug administration (MDA). Essential for program success is defining and confirming the appropriate endpoint for MDA when transmission is presumed to have reached a level low enough that it cannot be sustained even in the absence of drug intervention. Guidelines advanced by WHO call for a transmission assessment survey (TAS) to determine if MDA can be stopped within an LF evaluation unit (EU) after at least five effective rounds of annual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium vivax, which causes malaria.

 

Option B. P. falciparum: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium falciparum, another cause of malaria.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Transmission assessment surveys are not used for Leishmania species, which cause leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) are essential tools used to evaluate the success of mass drug administration programs for lymphatic filariasis and determine if the transmission levels are low enough to discontinue these programs.

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. tuberculosis

 

  • Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell wall.
  • It is released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis.
  • Urine LAM testing is especially useful in diagnosing TB in patients with HIV and low CD 4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, and its diagnosis is typically made through skin biopsy and slit-skin smear. Urine LAM is not used for diagnosing leprosy.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma species cause respiratory and urogenital infections. They lack a cell wall and, therefore, LAM is not relevant to their diagnosis.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterial pathogen causing listeriosis, diagnosed typically through blood culture or cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Urine LAM is not applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.
